awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports work performed by the National Radio Astronomy Observatory (NRAO) on the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) under a contract to the National Astronomical Observatory of Japan (NAOJ). The NAOJ desires NRAO to design and produce sensitive detector components for ALMA. ALMA enables transformational research into the physics of the cold Universe, regions that are optically dark but shine brightly in the millimeter/submillimeter portion of the electromagnetic spectrum. 

Within the broad range of science accessible with ALMA, the top-level objectives include imaging the redshifted dust continuum and molecular line emission from evolving galaxies as early as a redshift of z~10 (500 million years after the Big Bang), determining the chemical composition and dynamics of star-forming gas in normal galaxies like the Milky Way but at z~3 (75% of the way across the Universe), and measuring the gas kinematics in young disks in nearby star-forming clouds. ALMA has already demonstrated its revolutionary impact with its dramatic images of planet, star and galaxy formation. These results will accelerate as the full array becomes operational, and with the longest baselines ALMA will achieve an angular resolution of tens of milli-arseconds. ALMA provides one to two orders-of-magnitude improvement over previous facilities in all areas of millimeter- and submillimeter-wave observations, including sensitivity, angular resolution and image fidelity.

NRAO will design and produce ALMA Band 1 (35-50 GHz) low noise amplifiers and associated test and support equipment. The specific details regarding performance, materials, schedules, and other conditions are subject to the provisions of the Statements of Work and contracts between AUI/NRAO and NAOJ.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this project was the production, development, and delivery of 160 low noise amplifiers (14 spares and 146 production units) for use in the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) Band 1 cartridges for the National Astronomical Observatory of Japan (NAOJ). 

All amplifiers required by the customer organization for their cartridge construction work articles were delivered on time.  Only the last few articles (formally designated as lifetime spares for the associated project) were delayed owing to the work slowdown associated with scheduling issues related to the observatory?s pandemic response; however, these delays were inconsequential to the larger project.  Schedule and budget were strictly adhered to, the slight budget overrun being attributable to the Infectious Disease Operating Status (IDOS) that caused temporary work stoppages. 

The following practices are considered favorable to the project and should be used as guidelines for future projects: 

  1. This construction task had accurate parts, labor, and contingency built into the budget at the outset, based on the formally agreed specifications;
  2. Technical lead kept management updated with the progress status regularly;
  3. Acceptance test reports were compiled and shared with the customer organization, and their authorization to ship recorded on JIRA tickets for each individual amplifier;
  4. Periodic reports were written and sent to the customer organization as agreed in the statement of work to formally keep them appraised of the progress and budget situation; and
  5. To address the scope and specification change issues, as and when they arose, there were regular discussions held with the customer organization as well as NRAO management to ensure that everyone was kept informed.
